msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599

msDesc.head: Johannes de Sancto Paulo, Liber virtutem medicinarum simplicium and other medical texts

summary.seg: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius MS 379/599 is a composite medical volume comprised of several roughly coeval parts copied by different scribes. The volume contains several medical treatises popular in western Europe in the 12th-14th centuries including the text known as the Compendium Salerni, works by Johannes de Sancto Paulo and Matthaeus Platearius on the healing properties of simples (i.e., remedies prepared with a single primary healing ingredient), and a text attributed to Petrus Hispanus on conditions affecting the eyes. There are also lesser-known texts in the manuscript, such as a compilation of medicines ascribed in the rubric to 'Magister Pontius de Sancto Egido', and a wide variety of other shorter, anonymous texts and remedies or charms to treat such ailments as leprosy, sores, or constipation.

The composite parts were probably all copied in England during the 13th century (although dates in the late 12th century or the early 14th century are possible). The date when all of the composite parts were united is unknown, but the composite parts have coexisted in this form since the late-15th or early-16th century as the volume still retains its late-15th or early-16th century binding, and there is a list of the contents of the volume on the front pastedown in a late-15th or early-16th century hand which refers to texts which appear across the composite sections of the volume.

Although not entirely intact as it has been rebacked in more recent times, the binding is an excellent example of late-15th or early-16th century decorative binding work. The binder used small tools and a panel stamp to impress floral, foliate, and animal motifs within geometric frames in a style particularly popular in Flanders and then England in the late-15th and early-16th centuries. On the rear cover of the volume there is a medieval label known as a 'fenestra' (Latin for 'window'); fenestras were made from a strip of parchment with a title written in ink (in this case Cure magistri poncii), protected by a layer of animal horn shaved thin enough to be transparent (the glazing in the window), and then held in place on a cover with small metal tacks hammered into the board. Complete medieval fenestras are relatively rare as they often had slightly rough or raised edges that would catch on things and tear away leaving only the holes for the tacks behind as evidence of their former presence on a binding.

This manuscript, like many others included in the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project was once owned or used by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , a doctor and physician to Edward IV. Marchall may have added the draft table of contents at the beginning of the manuscript on the front pastedown, which has now largely been cropped away. Marchall is certainly responsible for the gloss to the Curae Magistri Poncii de S. Egidio on ff. 114r-140r and he also added a title 'Gerardi' in the upper margin of the opening leaf of the Modus medendi Gerardi on f. 167r. Marchall may also have written the label in the fenestra on the rear cover; he was certainly particularly interested in the text as it is the only one in the volume to which he added substantial annotations, but as the binding probsbly post-dates Marchall's lifetime on stylistic grounds, if the fenestra-label is indeed in Marchall's hand, then it was presumably transferred from an earlier binding. Marchall's ownership or use of manuscripts is very well-attested, with forty-five surviving books (including this one) bearing evidence to connect him to them in some way; six others may have been his or accessed by him, and a further twelve are recorded but not traced. Marchall is known to have gathered together and (re-)arranged manuscripts and the 4-part composite construction of this manuscript (not including the pastedown fragments), suggests that this may be another manuscript that Marchall curated into its current form.

As described by Linda Voigts, the present manuscript is one of eighteen (possibly nineteen) manuscripts at Gonville and Caius College that may be linked to Marchall, and which were probably donated by him to Gonville Hall (as Gonville and Caius then was); King's College and Peterhouse, where the study of medicine was also supported, received gifts of books from him too. Thirteen manuscripts owned or used by Marchall (and another with possible Marchall connections) have been digitised, catalogued and conserved as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project:
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 59/153 (Voigts 1995, no. 2)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 98/50 (Voigts 1995, no. 4)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57 (Voigts 1995, no. 5)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 159/209 (Voigts 1995, no. 9)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 178/211 (Voigts 1995, no. 10)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 181/214 (Voigts 1995, no. 11)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620 (Voigts 1995, no. 12)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 373/593 (Voigts 1995, no. 13)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599 (Voigts 1995, no. 14)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623 (Voigts 1995, no. 16)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (Voigts 1995, no. 24)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 222 (Voigts 1995, no. 28)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.31 (Voigts 1995, no. 29)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9213 (possible Marchall connections) (Voigts 1995, no. 48)

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

References: See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314

foliation.note: Foliated in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the the upper outer corner of the first recto of each quire.

collation.p:
The manuscript is composed of four composite parts; the date of their union is unknown but all parts were almost certainly together by the end of 15th century. The original quire structure is not intact, occasional text-leaves are missing throughout and an entire quire of eight leaves has been lost between Quires 11 and 12. Many of the quires are slightly irregular and are arranged as follows:
Quire 18 (ff. 1-8)
Quire 2?twelve (stitching visible between ff. 13v and 14r; ff. 9-20) |
Quires 3-68 (ff. 21-52)
Quire 74 (ff. 53-56) |
Quires 8-98 (ff. 57-72)
Quire 108-2 (3rd and 4th cancelled; ff. 73-78)
Quire 118 (ff. 79-86)
Quire 1210-3 (1st missing, 4th, and 5th cancelled; ff. 87-93)
Quire 136 (ff. 94-99)
Quire 148-1+1 (original 8th leaf excised, probably blank; singleton inserted after 7th leaf; ff. 100-107) |
Quires 15-1612 (ff. 108-131)
Quire 1710 (ff. 132-141)
Quires 18-238 (ff. 142-189)
Quire 246 (ff. 190-195)
collation.formula: 18 2?twelve | 3-68 74 | 8-98 108-2 (3rd and 4th cancelled) 118 1210-3 (1st missing, 4th and 5th cancelled) 136 148-1+1 (8th excised, singleton inserted after 7th) | 15-1612 1710 18-238 246

signatures.seg: Quires numbered in pencil in Hindu-Arabic numerals in the lower outer corner of the first recto of each quire. This quire designation sequence was probably added to the volume in the 19th century. Note that the designation for Quire 13 was inscribed incorrectly on f. 93r one leaf ahead of the start of Quire 13 on f. 94r.

binding.p: Fully bound in blind-stamped calf over wood boards with matching decoration to left and right covers. Covers are each decorated with two concentric triple-fillet frames with Oxford corners, the outer frame set at the perimeter of the boards, and the inner frame offset by c. 30mm from the perimeter of the boards. The space inside the inner frame is further subdivided into three horizontal sections, the upper and lower sections filled with matching decorative motifs achieved with a zoomorphic panel stamp of pairs of squirrels, dragons, eagles and ?vulning ?pelicans set in round frames, and the central section filled with closely set repetitions of a small square stamp of two birds with necks entwined.
On the left cover, an early modern hand has written a description of the volume very faintly in dark ink and now mostly faded: Liber [...] medicamendum cum alijs [...]

On the right cover there is a fenestra with original horn layer and metal tacks; the handwritten label bears the title of one of the works in the volume 'Cure magistri poncii' (referring to the Curae of Pontius de Sancto Aegido on ff. 114r-140r).

The overall design of the binding is similar to Flemish and then English bindings of the last quarter of the 15th century and the first quarter of the 16th century. As with most other finely cut decorative binding tools in use in England at this time, the zoomorphic panel stamp of four pairs of animals set in round frames was probably engraved in Flanders, and it may have been used there for a time before being imported into England. G. D. Hobson identified two other volumes that bear this stamp on their bindings:
- California, Huntingdon Library, 59497 - A copy of the Nova statuta angliae printed by Willem van Mechelen (William de Machlinia) Mechelen, Willem van, f. 1480 in London in 1484. An image of the binding can be viewed at The Scott Husby Database at Princeton University Library, no. 177611
- Bruges, Bruges Seminary, MS 003/164 - A late 13th or early 14th century bible, rebound in the late 15th or early 16th century. A digital facsimile of the manuscript and its binding can be viewed as part of the Mmmonk project here: Bruges, Bruges Seminary, MS 003/164

The manuscript has had a conservative recasing - the original stamped leather covers were lifted and new leather covers were wrapped around the wood boards, before the remains of the original leather covers were replaced on top of the new leather covers. Three raised bands on spine. Head and tail bands, if present, are capped by the replacement cover. The portion of the original leather covers over the back (i.e., the spine) of the volume is gone. The imprint of the original metal fittings for the fastening, probably a hook-and-catch clasp, is visible on the right cover, the original portion of the left cover at the site of the fastening has been torn away and the board underneath has a shallow irregular depression.
Two small printed paper labels affixed to the spine '599' in red and '379' in black indicating the current Gonville and Caius shelfmark.
See: Hobson, Blind-stamped panels in the English book-trade, c. 1485-1555 (1944), p. 10, fn. 1, and pl. 3b Oldham, Blind panels of English binders (1958), p. 18 and pl. AN. 21

history.acquisition: First recorded as part of the collection of Gonville and Caius College in 1600 as no. 42 in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600). However, the manuscript is likely to have been at Gonville Hall (as it then was) since the later part of the 15th century as it has annotations in the hand of physician and College manuscript donor, Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 . Marchall is known to have given several other medical volumes to the College and folios 108r-194r bear running headings in his hand. Marchall may also have added the rough table of contents to the front pastedown and may even have had the manuscript assembled and bound. See Voigts (1995) for further discussion.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on a description by M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, vol. II (1908)

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

custEvent.p: No. 42 in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600) as one of the manuscripts belonging to Gonville and Caius College.
No. 966 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599, ff. [i] and [ii]

msItem.title: Account roll relating to Ireland
msItem.note: Notes relating to the Hussey family including a Nicholas Hussey who is described as being the brother and heir of a Thomas Hussey who had recently been Baron [Galtrim]. The Thomas Hussey mentioned is presumably the 5th Baron Galtrim who was murdered before 1439, and the Nicholas is probably the 6th Baron Galtrim, Thomas' heir, who had died by 1493.

Note relating to a member of the Bottiler (Butler) family, describing him as an Earl of Ormond and one of the recent Chief Justicars of Ireland. Several members of the Butler family held this title and this role between 1359 and 1427.
Several references to the counties of Louth and Meath, and references to places including Dunboyne, Kilkenny, Rathfarnham and others.

msItem.title: Fragmentary table of contents
msItem.note: Partial list of the contents of the volume, now mostly cropped away. Linda Voigts was able to reconstruct the following: 'two references to Platearius (two versions of De medicinis, the second incomplete, occupy fols 57r-103r, a text having to do with eyes (Secreta Petri Yspani ad Oculus, fols 142r-48r), and Tractatus de coitu, (Constantine, Liber Coitus, fols 49v-54v).' Linda Voigts has suggested that this may be an informal list of the contents of the volume in the hand of Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , who also added a gloss to the Curae Magistri Poncii de S. Egidio on ff. 107r-134r and running headers to the Modus medendi Gerardi on ff. 167r-195r, and may have written the label in the fenestra on the rear cover.

listBibl.bibl: See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314, esp. p. 272

extent.seg: Fragment comprising segments from an account book or roll, reused as the left and right pastedowns in this volume.

seg.note: Writing is cropped along all edges of the fragments, so original leaf size and written-space size cannot be determined.

supportDesc.condition: The leaf has been cut for use as the left and right pastedowns - some text lost. Some parts of the leaf worn away due to rubbing and perhaps worm damage.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. The fragments have a mise-en-page typically seen in account books and rolls with a narrower column on the left side of the page for each heading, and a wider column to the right with more detailed information.

handNote.p: Written in the English form of Cursiva Antiquior typically referred to as Anglicana.

origin.origDate: 15th century, probably after 1439 since the fragment refers to the heirs of Thomas Hussey (herede Thome Hussee nuper Baronis...), probably 5th Baron Galtrim, who died in 1439.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599, ff. 1-20

msItem.title: De simplicium medicinarum uirtutibus
msItem.author: Johannes de Sancto Paulo

rubric.locus: Incipit liber uirtutem medicinarum simplicium secundum iohannes de sancto paulo

msItem.incipit: 1r Cogitanti mihi de simplicibus medicinis
msItem.explicit: 5r non modicam parere utilitatem
msItem.note: Another hand has added a note to the rubric 'cum 13 aliis tractibus', i.e., 'with 13 other treatises' but the texts to which the note refers are not clearly identified.

listBibl.bibl: Printed in Omnia opera ysaac vol. II (Lyon, 1515), ff. 186v-189v
Edited by G. H. Kroemer in his dissertation (Leipzig, 1920)

msItem.title: Pomum ambre
msItem.incipit: 5r Pomum ambre duplicatum ad reuma suspendendum
msItem.explicit: 13v confice cum tena et resueretur in pixide
msItem.note: Unprinted.

msItem.title: ?Summa Floridie
msItem.incipit: 13v Sanitatem custodire est qui motu
msItem.explicit: 17r crocea reperitur

msItem.title: De morbis puerorum (Practica)
msItem.incipit: 17r Passiones puerorum adhuc in cunabulis
msItem.explicit: 18r et hoc fiat cum predictis
msItem.note: Another part of this text can be found in this volume on ff. 157v-167v.

msItem.title: Medical treatise
msItem.incipit: 18r Nota si uolueris
msItem.explicit: 20r adipis altis quantum sufficit et coclearia .ii. melle
msItem.note: 20v blank.

p.secFol: Part 2 - secundo folio f. 2r: Gipsus spodium

supportDesc.collation:
Two quires, the structure of the latter uncertain, but fundamentally a quire of ten with two further leaves. The final leaf of Quire 2 is c. 180 mm high (typical height c. 210 mm) with an uneven lower edge, perhaps the edge of a sheet of parchment.
Quire 18 (ff. 1r-8v)
Quire 2twelve (ff. 9r-20v): stitching visible between ff. 13v and 14r
No leaf signatures particular to this Part.
No quire signatures particular to this Part. No catchwords particular to this Part.

layout.seg: Ruled in light brown ink, frame and lines, single column, typically 44 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a compressed and bold Textualis Libraria or perhaps even a Textualis Currens, with irregularity in the letterforms and frequent rushed and incomplete strokes. Crossed Tironian et.

decoNote.p: Initials in red, Lombardic Capital forms, 1-3 lines high at the start of each significant section of text, typically 3-10 per leaf.
Rubricated (red only) headings to each new significant section of text. Main title of work not rubricated, added instead in light brown ink in the upper margin of 1r perhaps in a later hand.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599, ff. 21-56

msItem.title: Compendium Salerni
msItem.incipit: 21r Multiplici me causa cogente dilectissimi socii
msItem.explicit: 35v et reliqua ad modum precedencium informabitur
msItem.note: Capitula list on f. 21rv.

msItem.title: De dandis medicinis
msItem.incipit: 35v In dandis medicinis talis sit ordo mane damus
msItem.explicit: 49r et meridie in modus castanee

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.incipit: 49r Contra leprum . Anguis accipiatur et abscisis capite et cauda tum
msItem.explicit: 49r postea fiant stupe ut alias scripsi

msItem.title: Two charms for the sick under the heading 'contra felon'
msItem.note: The first charm contains a version of the 'Tigað Tigað Tigað' incantation also found in London, British Library, MS Harley 585, f. 136rv and Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Junius 163, f. 227r. See Storms, Anglo-Saxon Magic (The Hague, 1948) pp. 301-302. Storms prints the first of the two charms in the Gonville and Caius manuscript on p. 302.

msItem.title: Liber maior de coitu
msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.rubric: 49v Hic incipit liber coitus collectus ex dictis multorum medicorum tam coitum explere non ualentibus subueniens quam abstinere uolentibus
msItem.incipit: 49v Creator uolens animalium genus
msItem.explicit: 54v a renibus asini abstracto ad ignem ungito mirem est
msItem.note: The text usually finishes with a treatment ending 'in qua cocta fuerit solum apium', but this treatment appears as the penultimate item in the text copied by this scribe. The final treatment in this version of the text is for 'libidinem prouocandem'.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes in Latin
msItem.note: These recipes follow the Liber maior de coitu each copied by a different scribe.

msItem.title: Dynamidia ad Maecenatem
msItem.author: Ps.-Galen
msItem.incipit: 55r Libellum quem rogasti
msItem.explicit: 56r et componere uelut creationem
msItem.note: This manuscript contains the shorter form of the text, and finishes at the end of the Ep. ad Macenatem.
This text was traditionally attributed to Galen, but the attribution is no longer believed to be correct.
A branching diagram on the humoral qualities hot, cold, wet, and dry follows the text.

msItem.title: Medical recipes in Latin
msItem.note: One of the recipes on f. 56v is eTK 1374G.

msItem.title: Note recording the lengths of the reigns of the English kings from William I to John.
msItem.note: In the lower margin.

note.p:
The lengths of the reigns are given as follows:
William 'the Bastard' - 23 years
Wiliam 'Rufus' - 13 years
Henry (I) - 35 years
Stephen - 19 years
Henry (II) - 36 years
Richard - 10 years
John - 10 years

King John reigned from May 1199 to October 1216, more than the 10 years given in this list, and given that John is the last king to appear in the list, it is possible that the list was copied when John was in the 10th year of his reign, i.e., 1209/1210.

p.secFol: Part 3 - secundo folio f. 22r: Medicina est sciencia apponendi modum

support.material: Parchment (HFFH). Folio 28 28rv is roughly half the width of a typical leaf; the text conforms to the narrower leaf dimensions.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines, typically 36 lines to the page. Mainly single columns, but f. 21rv ruled in double columns for capitula. Written above top line.

handNote.p: Written in late protogothic minuscule by at least three scribes working on the main texts and adding various marginal annotations.

decoNote.p: Illustration of a stylised plant executed in red and blue linework in the outer margin of f. 55r.
Decorated initial 'M' in dark blue and red with white acanthus frills on f. 21r.
Puzzle initials in red and blue on ff. 22r, 22v, 23v, 34r, 35v and 46r.

Pen-flourished initials in red and blue throughout at the start of many of the minor sections, either a red initial with blue pen-flourishing or the inverse. Some initials in this style have acanthus-leaf and botanical flourishing as well as the typical labrynthine style flourishing.
Coloured initials in alternating red and blue at the start of each capitulum entry on f. 21rv.
Rubrics (red only) to mark the beginnings and ends of texts or sections of texts on ff. 35v, 49v and 55r.
Stylised botanical line filler in red on 55v.

origin.origDate: Written in the early 13th century, possibly in or before 1210.
origin.p: The regnal list added in the lower margin of f. 56r lists the kings of England and the lengths of their reigns from William I to John; the entry for John's reign is given as 10 years and not the correct 17 years, so it is possible that the regnal list was copied in the 10th year of the reign of King John, i.e., 1209-1210, with the main text copied before that date.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599, ff. 57r-107r

msItem.title: De simplicibus medicinae ('Circa instans')
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius
msItem.incipit: 57r In presenti negocio circa simplices medicinas
msItem.explicit: 99r hic leto fine illud concludimus . hactenus archanum salerne diximus urbis littera iam lasso pollice sistit opus
msItem.finalRubric: 99r liber platearii crisostomi de medicina pro quo fuit intoxicatus ab inuidis et mortuus est

msItem.title: Poem on the medicinal degrees
msItem.incipit: 57r Primus dicatur in quo sensus dominatur . sensibus equito gaudet natura secundo
msItem.explicit: 57r Tercius excedit cuius tolleranciam ledit . Destractos sensus nescit preducere quartus
msItem.note: In the upper margin.

msItem.title: Medical recipes including extracts from the De simplicibus medicinae
De complexionibus
msItem.incipit: 103v Complexio est prima in unocumque elementorum coniunctio
msItem.explicit: 105v ut rura collentibus . ecplict

msItem.title: Liber aureus (extract): Chapters 1-2
msItem.author: Iohannes Afflacius
msItem.incipit: 106r Si dolor capitis sit ex causa
msItem.explicit: 106v in hac passione uox pre dolore

msItem.title: Text on constipation
msItem.incipit: 107r in quanto plus aquam aspergunt
msItem.explicit: 107r et forma inde magdaliones . optima suppositoria sunt in acutis contra constipationem

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: 107r Edificauit noe altare domino . Minatur nos aliquando dominus
msItem.explicit: 107v ut cum illo regnare valeamus . Qui V. E. d. l. AMEN

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: 107v Conuertimini ad me in toto corde
msItem.explicit: 107v modis peccauerat

p.secFol: Part 4 - secundo folio f. 58r: et exsiccari modicum permittatur

foliation.note: Leaves paginated in the upper outer corner of each recto and verso in ink in early 13th century Hindu-Arabic notation. Each numeral is surrounded by punctae. Some numbers have been lost to trimming.

There is an interruption to the medieval pagination sequence that suggests the loss of an entire quire between Quires 11 and 12. Folios 57r-83v have the medieval pagination pp. 1-54. The medieval pagination is absent from the leaves ff. 84r-86v. The medieval pagination resumes on 87r beginning with the page number '79' and continues until the designation p. '103' on f. 99r. The jump between the medieval 'page 54' and the medieval 'page 79' indicates a gap of 12 leaves, i.e., medieval pages 55-78. Folios 84-86 are probably medieval pages 55-60, with the numbering trimmed away. Medieval pages 77-78 can be accounted for by the loss of the first leaf of Quire 12. The remaining 16 pages between medieval pages 61 and 76 indicate the loss at this point of a quire of 8 leaves, the typical structure for a quire in this section of the manuscript.

collation.p:
Seven quires, typically of eight leaves. The gap in the medieval pagination between Quires 11 and 12 indicates a loss of an entire quire of eight leaves at this point.
8-98 (ff. 57-72)
108-2 (3rd and 4th cancelled) (ff. 73-78)
118 (ff. 79-86)
1210-3 (ff. 87-93: 1st missing, 4th, and 5th cancelled)
136 (ff. 94-99)
148+1-1 (ff. 100-107
collation.signatures: Medieval quire signature 'II' in faint brown ink in the lower margin of f. 72v. Medieval quire signature 'III' in faint brown ink in the lower margin of f. 78v.

layout.seg: Ruled in light brown ink, frame and lines in a single column format. Typically 40 lines to the page, but some leaves are ruled for a more sparse or dense format. Written above top line. The final leaf in this part of the manuscript, f. 107v is unruled.

handNote.p: Written by several scribes in late protogothic minuscules of varying calligraphic quality.

decoNote.p: Illustration of a man in a cloak and headband holding a flower executed in red and blue linework in the outer margin of f. 57r, probably intended as an illustration of Mattheus Platearius, the author of the adjacent text. Illustration of a bird's head in the inner margin, and a bipedal dragon in the outer margin executed in red and blue linework on f. 59r. Illustration of a stylised flower in red and blue linework in the outer margin of f. 60r. Illustration of a stylised flower in red and blue linework in the inner margin of f. 71r. Illustration of a stylised goat's head in red and brown linework in the inner margin of f. 73v. Illustration of a seated human male wrapped in a cloak and pointing at folding tablets in red and blue linework in the outer margin of f. 92v. Illustration of a human male head in blue and brown linework in the inner margin of f. 93r.
Puzzle initials in red and blue and with pen-flourished decoration at the openings of major sections of text or new texts, e.g., f. 57r.
Pen-flourished initials in red and blue, either a red initial with blue flourishing or the reverse at the openings of minor sections of text, typically 3-5 per page.

Rubrication (red only) at the openings of most major sections of text. The topic of each section of text is given in red in the outer margins of ff. 57r-93v. Paraph marks typically in brown ink and touched with red throughout.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599, ff. 108r-195v

msItem.title: Medical Treatise (unidentified)
msItem.rubric: 108r Incipiunt cure magistri poncii de sancto Egido
msItem.incipit: 108r Consideracio elementorum . ab elementis . habet ortum
msItem.explicit: 113v et misce cit
msItem.note: This item bears the rubricated title 'Cure magistri Poncii de sancto Egido', but the text that follows is not actually that text, but rather another, unidentified medical treatise. The Curae of Pontius de Sancto Egidio appears on ff. 114r-140r.
The names of several Arabic authors appear in this text.
CUL is grateful to Professor Peter Jones for his advice when cataloguing this Item. Any errors in this Item are the responsibility of the author of this record.

msItem.title: Curae
msItem.author: Pontius de Sancto Aegido
msItem.rubric: 114r Cure omnium egritudinum quod accidunt a summitate capitis usque ad epiglotum sed quam hic nominantur et primo de melancolica passione . contra melancolicam passione
msItem.incipit: 114r Contra melancholicam passionem. In primis digeratur materia cum isto sirupo
msItem.explicit: 140r et fac emplastrum supra locum dolentem
msItem.note: The rubric here is a close match for Vatican City, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, MS 2459, ff. 33r-46r
CUL is grateful to Professor Peter Jones for his advice when cataloguing this Item. Any errors in this Item are the responsibility of the author of this record.

msItem.title: Antidotarum Guileberti
msItem.author: Gilbert (ascr.)
msItem.incipit: 140r medice accedens ad pacientem
msItem.explicit: 141r lapis lazuli abluti . et huius hoc . omnia diligenter considera et attendas
msItem.finalRubric: 141r Explicit antidotarium Guilberti . Explicit antidotarium Guilberti
msItem.note: Ascribed in the manuscript to 'Guilbert' (perhaps Gilbertus AnglicusGilbertus, Anglicus?).
CUL is grateful to Professor Peter Jones for his advice when cataloguing this Item. Any errors in this Item are the responsibility of the author of this record.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for a sore stomach and a lack of appetite
Medical recipe for the treatment of ?a fistula?
De egritudinibus oculorum
msItem.author: Petrus Hispanus, medicus compilator
msItem.rubric: 142r Secreta magistri petri yspani ad oculos
msItem.incipit: 142r In nomine summi opificii
msItem.explicit: 149r acceptis de pectine matris
msItem.note: This Petrus Hispanus has traditionally been identified, but probably wrongly, with Petrus Hispanus the writer on logic, or alternatively and with Petrus Juliani, the future Pope John XXI, both of whom are probably to be distinguished from 'magister Petrus Hispanus medicus', active in Siena c. 1245-50.

msItem.title: Liber cardinalis de morbis oculorum
msItem.incipit: 149r Cum sint oculi corporis lucerna
msItem.explicit: 152r appone ad pondus trium denariorum . et coque ad mellis spissitudinem No . inunge
msItem.note: Text finishes in lower margin of f. 152r.

msItem.title: Medical treatise on cures
msItem.incipit: 152v In primis refero deo omnipotenti gracias
msItem.explicit: 157v Postea accipiantur ii partes pulueris thuris et vna sulfuris . fiat unguentum .
msItem.note: Prologue before main text. Main text perhaps begins at: VIdi hominem qui habebat bene 45 annos et eius os erat distortum . ad modum paralitici.
Compare with London, British Library, Sloane MS 340, ff. 81r-98v

msItem.title: De morbis (Practica) puerorum
msItem.incipit: 157v PAssiones puerorum . ad huc in cunabilis lacencium . sub breui . placuit mihi tractare compendio
msItem.explicit: 167r in naribus infunde et statim loquetur

msItem.title: De modo medendi
msItem.author: Gherardo of Cremona
Gerard of Montpellier
msItem.incipit: 167r Cvm omnis scientia ex suo fine et utilitate sua . sit appenda maxime ars medicinalis est appetenda cum eius finis sit laudabilis
msItem.explicit: 195r si non habes in oleo communi. et in fine appone puluerem castore . et cum
msItem.note: Work variously attributed both to Gherardo of Cremona and Gerard of Montpellier.

msItem.title: Medical recipes in Latin
msItem.note: Medical recipes in several hands. Roughly a third of the leaf has been cut away.

p.secFol: Part 5 - secundo folio, f. 109r: racem tepidi et cum betonica

support.material: Parchment (HFFH). Leaves trimmed with losses to marginal annotations throughout.

supportDesc.foliation: Two sets of medieval foliation: one in the centre of the upper margin in ink in Hindu-Arabic numerals, starting at '1' on 108r; the other in the centre of the lower margin in ink in Roman numerals, starting at 'i' on 108r. Note that this foliation has dittography errors across leaves and so ends up diverging from the 'correct' leaf count after f. 123r.

collation.p:
Ten quires. The gap in the medieval foliation between the end of Quire 19 and the beginning of Quire 20 (ff. 157v-158r) suggests the loss of a whole quire at this point. Quire 24 was probably originally a quire of 8; the third leaf of the quire is probably missing as the medieval foliation jumps by one leaf between the present ff. 190-191, and the original final leaf is either missing or cancelled.
Quires 15-1612 (ff. 108-131)
Quire 1710 (ff. 132-141)
Quires 18-238 (ff. 142-189)
Quire 246 (ff. 190-195)

signatures.p: No quire signatures in this Part.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in the lower inner corner of the last verso of some quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in faint brown ink, frame and lines in two columns. Written below top line, typically 40 lines to the column.

handNote.p: Written in a northern textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Coloured initials in red at the start of some texts, many texts have space for the initial and a guide letter, but no initial.
Guide letters for coloured initials in the margins of most leaves, many initials unfilled, many guide letters partially or totally lost to trimming.
Rubrics (in red) at the start of most texts and at the start of new sections within each text. Paraph marks in red. Initials at the start of minor sections often in brown and touched with red.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer for Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
